If you're going to write about science, and particularly baboon behavior, I wish you wouldn't express your tittering embarrassment about masturbation, which is what I think the baboon was doing. News stories aren't supposed to be a guessing game.

Some people are offended by sex. I'm offended by snickering about sex.

There was a time when the NYT avoided sex. Under A.M. Rosenthal, you were't allowed to use the word "penis."

During the beginning of the AIDS epidemic, it was life-saving information to know that AIDS was spread by receptive anal intercourse. The newspapers, includng the NYT, were too prudish to report that. So people had to depend on rumors and misinformation, rather than newspapers, to know what was safe.

What's more important to you -- telling the truth, and giving people information they need to save their lives, or accommodating victorian prudery and hypocrisy?

I thought that Jane Brody and Olivia Judson had put an end to that.

We now have politicians who are trying to eliminate sex, evolution and global warming from our schools. Prudery and embarrassment is a big problem in science education. I shouldn't have to be subject to it in a serious newspaper.

If you can't write seriously about sex, don't write about science.

#8 is harping on the shop-worn "50% don't pay any taxes." First, they do pay taxes - Social Security and Medicare contributions, sales taxes, federal and state taxes on gasoline, alcohol and tobacco, state income taxes. And they *do* pay federal income tax, but not much - for the simple reason that they don't make any money.

I suggest you go to the IRS web site and download the statistics on income tax since 1986 (and go to the tax foundation to get the numbers back to 1980). In 2007 - *before* the crash, which resulted in millions of layoffs - the Adjusted Gross Income required to put you in the top 50% was $34,000. That's right, 50% of the individuals and households in this, "the richest country in the world", reported incomes of less than $34,000. The top 25% earn 2/3 of the national income. The top 50% earn *7/8* of the country's income. The bottom 50% earned 12+% of the nation's income, the top 1% earned *22%* - over 2$ trillion of the $8.4 trillion total.

Comparing the percentages of 2007 with those of 1980 - the year Ronald Reagan was elected - we see that the transfer from the lower 95% to the top 5% amounts (as of 2007) to 1/6 of the national income every year, and it's still growing. In 2007, that amounted to $1.45 trillion - over $10,000 *per tax return* in the lower 95. The bottom 50% has lost 1/3 of their share, the 50-75% bracket has lost 1/4 of their share; the middle class is steadily being impoverished.

The rich are already paying most of the taxes, because they have all the income. But they need to pay more. In Bernie Sander's words, "Let those who took the profits pay for the bailout."

Airlines have not always had this policy.  And in fact, there used to be children's fares that were much less than adult fares.  For my son's 9th birthday in 1973, we put him on a PSA plane in Los Angeles and let him fly alone to San Francisco, where my brother and sister-in-law met him and took him out for the day, sending him home the same way that night.  The fare, if I remember correctly, was $19 each way.  And not only did my son enjoy the trip, he talked his way into the cockpit before takeoff on the way up.

Yes, we need manufacturing.
We have 300 million people to support and a thriving manufacturing base is essential to our economy.
The flight of our manufacturing base over the past 30 years is one great reason for our economic woes today.
Americans need to develop new businesses that satisfy the manufacturing needs of a number of industries.
And to do that, we need to improve our educational system so that it is more responsive to the needs of new manufacturing businesses.
Encouraging ingenuity has been one of America's secret reasons for its success in the past and it can be again in the future if we work to develop an innovative climate for industry.

Since we all seem to believe it's a good idea to pass out hundreds of millions to manufacturing start-ups, and since democracy is in essence just a big bull session where everybody gets to say their piece, then I vote that we invest, say, $800 million in my new manufacturing company that manufactures green stuff. Green stuff? Yeah, that's right, green stuff! And every job that I, er ... you taxpayers, create will be a green job because they make green stuff.

What do you say?

For thirty years, the U.S. has embraced an ideology that government should never be allowed to make core investments to promote growth industries. While Asian countries invested publicly and then zoomed ahead, we insisted on fighting with one arm tied behind our backs, seemingly out of spite for that left arm. Not surprisingly, private investment went to where the investing was better.

We now have a new opportunity. Lithium technology is just one field that we can choose to pursue -- if it isn't already too late -- but to do that will require a reversal of our defeatist economic ideology. We need to realize that a nation in debt can't just 'pay' its way out by holding its breath, but has to 'grow' its way out. Private investment hasn't sufficed -- and cannot suffice -- to produce the growth we need.

Let's now choose the plan that has been proven to work better: by taxing the excesses that now lie fallow, and making intelligent public investment in growth industries.

For too many of us the wars this country fights are far removed, reduced to headlines in a newspaper, an occasional heartfelt moment when the death of an unknown neighbor is told over local television, but for many of us the wars live in our home; we are the families of those who serve or have served. Our lives, forever changed, carry the reality of war, and though none of us ask for special consideration we all expect that every American understand that an untold price is paid by some of us not shared by all Americans. It's time, that as Americans we openly discuss a real end to these war without being shutdown or censored by the media. It's time that our candidate for president, a man who promises to bring our men home, be heard and not labeled. It's time that responsible journalist come to the aid of nation torn by a decade of war and stand against the bias that silences his words of peace. We don't ask the nation to pay our price, we only asked that our candidate be heard. Ron Paul has a message for peace we believe should be heard by all Americans.

I am a small manufacturer in the woodworking tooling industry. I have seen hundreds of thousands of good, middle-class, blue-collar jobs in just the woodworking industry sent overseas by a short-sighted, yet government, financing and corporate-endorsed shifts over the past 30 years.

It's not all high-tech as reviewed in this article. It's our basic commodities. We've lost not only the jobs, but the machine tool industry, the tool rooms, the support and supply industries, the patent process rationality, and the overall valuing of manufacturing - hence the title of the article.

All because a bizarre corporate and national policy was invoked and put into play, serving short term profits, eliminating higher paying jobs, and dispensing with that nasty process of manipulating actual materials and processes.

We can't forget that the education and schooling of our workforce - both in technical, social and liberal arts skills (yup, reading, writing, thinking, inquiry) - is being decimated by a conservative Republican war on education, labor, unions, rational thinking and science.

It's nice to think that government support to focused high-tech industries and research will be enough to restore our manufacturing strength. It's not. We have to think more broadly about what kind of nation we wish to be, and how we will not only compete in the global economy, but also take care of our own citizens, workers, children and environment.

Going cheap and short term isn't enough.
